title: A Sign at the Beautiful Gate
subtitle: Acts 3:1-10
teaser: Peter and John encounter a man who has been lame from birth. He expects money. Instead, he receives healing in the name of Jesus. This miracle is not merely compassionate — it is strategic. It is a sign that the ministry of Jesus has not ended. It has expanded.
anchorVerse: Then Peter said, 'Silver or gold I do not have, but what I do have I give you. In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk.' — Acts 3:6 (NIV)
theme: Signs and the Authority of Jesus' Name

emphasis: Silver or gold I do not have, but what I do have I give you
In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk
He jumped to his feet and began to walk

keyVerse.text: Then Peter said, 'Silver or gold I do not have, but what I do have I give you. In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk.'

modules.passage:
One day Peter and John were going up to the temple at the time of prayer — at three in the afternoon. Now a man who was lame from birth was being carried to the temple gate called Beautiful, where he was put every day to beg from those going into the temple courts. When he saw Peter and John about to enter, he asked them for money. Peter looked straight at him, as did John. Then Peter said, 'Look at us!' So the man gave them his attention, expecting to get something from them.

Then Peter said, 'Silver or gold I do not have, but what I do have I give you. In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk.' Taking him by the right hand, he helped him up, and instantly the man's feet and ankles became strong. He jumped to his feet and began to walk. Then he went with them into the temple courts, walking and jumping, and praising God. When all the people saw him walking and praising God, they recognized him as the same man who used to sit begging at the temple gate called Beautiful, and they were filled with wonder and amazement at what had happened to him.

words.rootMeaning: In the ancient world, a person's 'name' meant their identity, character, and legal authority. When Peter says, 'In the name of Jesus,' he is not performing a religious formula. He is invoking the living authority of the risen Christ.

sections.title: What's Happening in Acts 3?
sections.body: Two ordinary apostles walk into the Temple for the afternoon prayer service. One extraordinary moment changes everything: A beggar looks for coins. Peter offers Christ. A body is restored. A crowd is awakened. A sermon is birthed. The church steps into the public eye. This miracle is not merely compassionate — it is strategic. It is a sign that the ministry of Jesus has not ended. It has expanded.

modules.keyInsight: A beggar expected coins, but Peter offered Christ. The first public miracle of the church redirected expectations from human resources to divine authority.
modules.heading: A Sign at the Beautiful Gate

sections.title: The Birth of an Unlikely Movement (Part 1 of 5)
sections.body:
In 1785, a 26-year-old British politician named William Wilberforce sat alone on a hilltop in the English countryside, wrestling with a conviction he could neither escape nor explain. He had recently experienced what he called 'the great change' — a sincere conversion to Christianity that reoriented his entire understanding of purpose and responsibility. But now he faced a terrifying question: Could he remain in Parliament and still follow Christ wholeheartedly?

At that time, politics was known for bribery, ego, and ruthless ambition. Many new believers abandoned public life to embrace private devotion. Wilberforce wondered if he must do the same.

Unsure, he sought counsel from the aging former slave-ship captain turned Anglican minister John Newton, author of Amazing Grace. Newton told him something shocking: 'God has raised you up for this very thing. Stay in Parliament. Serve Him there.'

It was in the wake of that conversation that Wilberforce learned about the horrors of the transatlantic slave trade — the overcrowded ships, the brutal conditions, the staggering loss of life.

He had no plan, no strategy, no idea how fierce the opposition would be. What he had was conviction — a sense that God was calling him into public witness, not private retreat.

At that moment, Wilberforce felt wildly unqualified. The political system was stacked against him. The slave trade was economically entrenched. The opposition would be powerful. But what he did next mirrored the pattern we see in Acts: He gathered a small group of believers. They prayed. They sought the Spirit's guidance. They committed themselves to truth, integrity, and courage.

Before the speeches, before the campaigns, before the votes — the movement began in quiet rooms, in prayer, in the company of a handful of people who believed Jesus still acted through His followers.

modules.connectionToTheme: Every public work of God begins in hidden places — in conviction, prayer, obedience, and the courage to say yes before you know the cost.
modules.heading: True Story: The Birth of an Unlikely Movement

sections.title: The Temple is no longer the only place where God acts
sections.body: The miracle happens in the Temple courts, but the power does not come from the Temple system. It comes from Jesus — the new and better Temple.

sections.title: The apostles continue the ministry of Jesus
sections.body: Compare Acts 3 with Luke 5 and Luke 7. The pattern is identical: a hurting person, a healing, a crowd, and a message. Luke is telling you: Jesus is still working — just through different hands.

sections.title: Miracles create gospel opportunity, not entertainment
sections.body: Peter immediately redirects the crowd: 'This is not about us. This is about Jesus.' Signs are not the point. They point to the point.

sections.title: The healing symbolizes salvation itself
sections.body: Lameness meant exclusion from full Temple participation. Healing meant restoration to community, worship, and identity. That is what salvation is — restoration.

modules.fascinatingFact: The gate called 'Beautiful' (Greek: Horaia) was likely the Nicanor Gate, made of Corinthian bronze and considered the most magnificent entrance to the Temple. The contrast is striking: at the most beautiful gate in Jerusalem, a man sits in the ugliest condition — excluded, dependent, forgotten. Jesus' power transforms the scene.
modules.heading: Deeper Context

modules.ancientTruth: Peter offered what he had — not silver or gold, but the living authority of Jesus. The miracle at the Beautiful Gate demonstrated that Jesus' ministry had not ended with His ascension but expanded through His followers.
modules.modernApplication: We are often tempted to offer people small solutions — advice, positivity, encouragement — when God may be inviting us to offer the presence and authority of Jesus instead. The question is not whether we have enough resources, but whether we are willing to offer what we actually have.

connectionPoints.then: A lame man expected coins from passersby at the Temple gate.
connectionPoints.now: People around us often expect small comforts when God wants to offer transformative encounter.

connectionPoints.then: Peter redirected the man's expectations from human charity to divine authority.
connectionPoints.now: We are called to point people beyond human solutions to the living power of Christ.

connectionPoints.then: The miracle was not random — it was a sign pointing to Jesus' ongoing ministry.
connectionPoints.now: Every act of faith we take in Jesus' name is a sign that He is still at work in the world.

modules.prompt: Where am I offering people small solutions when God might be inviting me to offer the presence and authority of Jesus instead?
additionalQuestions: What 'silver and gold' am I relying on instead of the name of Jesus?
Where is God asking me to step into a situation with nothing but faith?
Who in my life needs more than advice — they need an encounter with Christ?

modules.scriptureEcho: Based on Peter's declaration in Acts 3:6
modules.prayerText: Lord Jesus, Your name carries power, compassion, and authority. Forgive me when I rely on my own resources instead of Your presence. Teach me to see interruptions as invitations, and to give others what You've given me — Yourself. Jesus, give me the courage to offer You. Amen.

modules.commitment: Today, ask God for one opportunity to offer something deeper than advice, positivity, or 'silver and gold.' Look for one moment where you can point someone toward Jesus rather than offering a lesser comfort.
